questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe allergic reaction symptoms, including urticaria and hypotension, after ingesting a shrimp. How does the vasoactive mediator involved primarily cause hypotension?

options.A: Dilating arterioles and increasing vascular permeability
options.B: Enhancing nitric oxide production and vasodilation
options.C: Inducing the release of other pro-inflammatory cytokines
options.D: Inhibiting platelet aggregation and causing clotting

questions.explanation: Correct Answer : A) Dilating arterioles and increasing vascular permeability Explanation: Histamine is the vasoactive mediator responsible for hypotension in severe allergic reactions, such as anaphylaxis as given in the scenario. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, page 86

questions.question: Which type of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) is involved in microbial killing and is induced in macrophages by cytokines or microbial products?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Inducible NOS (iNOS) Explanation: Inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) is involved in microbial killing. iNOS generates nitric oxide (NO) from Arginine which reacts with superoxide (O2•) to produce peroxynitrite (ONOO − ). Peroxynitrite helps combat infections. Type Constitutive Expression Function Endothelial (eNOS) Low levels Maintains vascular tone Neuronal (nNOS) Low levels Functions as a neurotransmitter Inducible (iNOS) Induced in macrophages(not constitutive expression) Involved in microbial killing, induced by cytokines or microbial products . Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, page no 83

questions.question: All are chemoattractants among the following except :
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D) C3b EXPLANATION : IL-8 , C5a and LTB4 are endogenous chemoattractants .These are primarily involved in NEUTROPHIL chemotaxis. TYPES OF CHEMOATTRACTANTS: EXOGENOUS ENDOGENOUS Exogenous factors are: Bacterial products, including peptides with N-formylmethionine terminal amino acids and some lipids. Endogenous chemoattractants include: Several chemical mediators (1) cytokines, particularly those of the chemokine family (e.g., IL-8 ); (2) components of the complement system, particularly C5a ; and (3) arachidonic acid (AA) metabolites, mainly leukotriene B4 ( LTB4 ). C3b(OPTION D): C3b is an opsonin and promotes phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages. It is not a chemoattractant. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 79.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with symptoms of flu-like illness, including fever, sore throat, and fatigue. Further investigation reveals a positive HIV serology. Which of the following chemokine receptors primarily facilitates the entry of HIV into CD4+ T cells?
questions.explanation: coreceptors for a viral envelope(gp120) glycoprotein of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the cause of AIDS, and thus facilitating the entry of HIV into CD4+ T cells. Chemokines: Chemokines are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins: C = Cysteine ; X = Any amino acid Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no - 90

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. Which of the following chemokines is primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations?
questions.explanation: recruitment of neutrophils to sites of inflammation, particularly in response to bacterial and other microbial infections. In COPD exacerbations, increased levels of CXCL8 are observed in the airways, contributing to the recruitment and activation of neutrophils, which exacerbate airway inflammation and tissue damage. MCP-1(OPTION B): monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), primarily recruits monocytes and macrophages to sites of inflammation. It is not primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways during exacerbations SDF-1(OPTION C): CXCL12, also known as stromal cell-derived factor 1 (SDF-1), is involved in stem cell homing and lymphocyte trafficking. It primarily attracts lymphocytes, monocytes, and hematopoietic stem cells but is not a major chemokine involved in recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations. RANTES(OPTION D): CCL5, also known as regulated on activation, normal T cell expressed and secreted (RANTES), attracts T cells, eosinophils, and basophils to sites of inflammation. While it contributes to the inflammatory response, it is not primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no - 90 , 680

questions.question: Which of the following mediators is responsible for cancer cachexia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) TNF-alpha Explanation: TNF-alpha is an inflammatory cytokine produced by macrophages and monocytes. Key roles include: WBC recruitment, vascular leak in acute inflammation Appetite suppression (via action on the hypothalamus), cancer cachexia Fever induction (along with IL1, IL6) Maintains granulomas in granulomatous diseases (eg. Tuberculosis) IFN-gamma (Option B) : IFNg is secreted by NK and T cells. Its key role is stimulating macrophages to kill phagocytosed organisms and form granulomas. IL-8 (Option C): IL-8 is a major chemoattractant for neutrophils in acute inflammation. TGF-beta (Option D): TGF-beta is predominantly involved in wound healing, stimulating angiogenesis and fibrosis. It is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 90.

questions.question: A 20-year-old male is prescribed naproxen for a musculoskeletal injury. What is naproxen’s mechanism of action?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cycloxygenase (COX) 1 and COX-2 inhibition Explanation: Arachidonic acid (AA), derived from phospholipids, is metabolized by cyclooxygenases (COX-1, COX-2) to form prostanoids (prostaglandins, thromboxane). COX-1 is a constitutive enzyme, predominantly involved in various homeostatic mechanisms in the body, while COX-2 is predominantly involved in inflammation. Prostaglandins are responsible for vasodilation (PGD2, PGI2) and pain (PGE2) in inflammation. Naproxen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). The predominant action of NSAIDs is via COX-1 and COX-2 inhibition, resulting in analgesia and anti-inflammatory effects which is required in this case of musculoskeletal injury.. One major adverse effect of NSAIDs is gastric irritation, including ulcers and bleeding. This occurs due to the loss of gastroprotective PGs i.e. PGE2 formed by COX-1. Thus, in patients with previous history of gastric ulcers, selective COX-2 inhibitors may be used - celecoxib, etoricoxib, etc. Lipoxygenase acts on AA to form leukotrienes. Leukotrienes have clinical significance in atopy and mediate anaphylaxis and bronchoconstriction. Zileuton (LOX inhibitor) and montelukast (LT receptor antagonists) are therefore used in asthma and allergic rhinitis but have no anti-inflammatory action (Option A). PGF2 is a prostanoid formed by cyclooxygenase. However, it has no role in inflammation. Rather, it causes smooth muscle contraction. Thus PGF2alpha analogue (carboprost) may be used to induce labor or as an abortifacient (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 98

questions.question: Select the correct statements about the complement system. 1) The complement system primarily functions by adaptive immunity. 2) Complement proteins are solely produced in the liver. 3) All complement proteins are synthesized in inactive forms and are activated by proteolysis. 4) Complement activation occurs through three pathways. 5) Complements have two equal fragments.
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D) 3,4 EXPLANATION: The correct statements regarding the complement system are statements 3 and 4. Complement System: The complement system is a collection of plasma proteins that function mainly in host defense against microbes and in pathologic inflammatory reactions. The system consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 through C9. The complement proteins function in both innate and adaptive immunity for defense against microbial pathogens. (Statement 1) Site of synthesis: (Statement 2) Liver (major site). Monocytes. Tissue macrophages. Epithelial cells of GIT and genitourinary tract. Activation of complement proteins occurs by three pathways: (Statement 4) Classical pathway. Alternative pathway. Lectin pathway. Activation of complement pathway: All complement proteins are synthesized in inactive forms and are activated by proteolysis. (Statement 3) Complements have two unequal fragments (small and large fragments). (Statement 5) The larger fragments are designated as ‘b’ (e.g., C3b), and the smaller fragments are designated as ‘a' (e.g., C3a) ( exception: C2a —larger fragment). The larger fragment participates in the complement pathway's cascade reaction , and the smaller fragment diffuses away to mediate other functions. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 90 Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apruba S Sastry, 3rd edition, Page no. 163

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a high fever, chills, and malaise. He reports feeling unwell for the past few days and has noticed redness and swelling around a cut on his forearm. On examination, the healthcare provider observes a localized area of erythema and induration at the site of the wound. Which of the following events is a crucial step in the activation of the complement system in response to the patient's initial condition?

options.A: Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes
options.C: Cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b
options.D: Cleavage of C5 by C5 convertase

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: C) Cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b EXPLANATION: Complement system is a plasma derived mediator of inflammation. Other plasma derived mediators of inflammation are Coagulation/Cloting and Kinin pathway. The complement system can be activated by three pathways: Classical pathway Triggered by the binding of C1 to an antibody (IgM or IgG) that has combined with the antigen. Activated by Ag-Ab complex. Alternate pathway Triggered by microbial surface molecules (e.g., endotoxin or lipopolysaccharide [LPS]), complex polysaccharides, cobra venom, and other substances in the absence of an antibody. Lectin pathway The plasma mannose-binding lectin binds to carbohydrates on microbes and directly activates C1. The cleavage of C3 into its active fragments, C3a and C3b , is the critical event in the complement system and serves as a central step in all three complement activation pathways. The image below shows an overview of the complement pathways.

questions.question: Match the following with their correct answers. 1 C3a i Decay accelerating factor 2 C3b ii EBV receptor 3 CR2 iii Anaphylatoxin 4 CD55 iv Opsonin
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-iii, 2-iv, 3-ii, 4-i Explanation: Anaphylatoxins: C3a, C4a, and C5a. Opsonins: C3b. CR2/CD21/C3d: Complement receptor for EBV entry into cells (T cells/macrophages) CD55: Decay accelerating factor. It accelerates the dissociation of C3 convertase, inhibiting all 3 pathways. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 91 Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 3rd edition, Page no. 167

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the alternate complement pathway?

options.A: Teichoic acid is an initiator of the alternate complement pathway.
options.B: The first complement protein to be activated is C1.
options.C: The C3 convertase of the alternate pathway is C3bBb.
options.D: Properdin deficiency involves the alternate pathway.

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) The first complement protein to be activated is C1. EXPLANATION: C1 is not associated with the alternate complement pathway. The complements involved in the alternate pathway are: Free C3 in the serum. Factor B. Factor D. Properdin. Activators (Initiators) of alternate pathway: Pathogens from microbes Non-microbial initiators Gram (-ve) bacteria: Endotoxins or lipopolysaccharides. Gram (+ve) bacteria: Teichoic acid. (Option A) Fungal cells: Yeast cells. Parasites: Trypanosoma. Virus-infected cells. Human antibodies in complexes: IgA, IgD. Tumor cells. Cobra venom factor. Heterologous RBCs from mice, rabbits, and chickens. Anion polymer like dextran sulfate. Pure carbohydrates like agar and inulin. The image below shows the three complement pathways. The table below shows the differences between the three complement pathways. Features Classical Alternate Lectin Activator (initiator) Antigen-antibody complex Endotoxin, IgA, IgD etc Carbohydrate residue of the bacterial cell wall (mannose-binding protein) that binds to the host lectin antigen 1st complement to be activated C1 C3 (Option B) C4 C3 convertase C14b2a C3bBb (Option C) MBL/MASP-C4b2a C5 convertase (C3 convertase + 3b) C14b2a3b C3bBb3b MBL/MASP-C4b2a3b Complement levels in the serum All C1-C9: Low C1, C2, C4: Normal Others: Low C1: Normal Others: Low Immunity Acquired Innate Innate Deficiency of properdin and factor D deficiency can lead to increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms (e.g. Neisseria) due to defects in the alternate pathway. (Option D)

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset swelling of her face, lips, and tongue. She reports a history of similar episodes occurring intermittently since childhood, often triggered by stress or trauma. On examination, she appears anxious and has marked swelling of her lips and tongue, with difficulty speaking and swallowing. There are no signs of urticaria or pruritus. Her vital signs are stable. Which of the following deficiencies is seen in this condition?

options.B: Deficiency of C1, C2, C3, C4

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: C) Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation of the patient with sudden-onset swelling of her face, lips, and tongue with similar episodes in the past, triggered by stress and trauma is suggestive of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is caused due to deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of non-pitting, non-pruritic swelling of the skin and mucous membranes. C1INH (C1 esterase inhibitor) blocks the catalytic function of C1. Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor leads to elevated plasma levels of bradykinin leading to angioedema, and excessive activation of C1 results in a decline in plasma C4 and C2 levels. Swelling in HAE commonly affects areas such as the face, lips, tongue, throat, and extremities and can lead to airway compromise if it involves the upper respiratory tract. Triggers for HAE episodes can vary but commonly include stress, trauma, hormonal fluctuations (e.g., menstruation), and certain medications (e.g., estrogen-containing contraceptives) Complement deficiency Pathway(s) involved Disease (pathology) Properdin (Option A) Alternative pathway Increased susceptibility to encapsulated organisms (Neisseria) C1, C2, C3, C4 (Option B) C1, C2, C4- Classical pathway C3- Common pathway SLE, glomerulonephritis, pyogenic infections C5-C9: Membrane attack complex (Option D) Common deficiency Disseminated Neisseria infection( gram negative bacteria) Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no. 2723 Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 3rd edition, Page no. 168 Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 90-92

questions.question: Which of the following deficiencies is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) CD59 EXPLANATION: A clinical presentation of a patient with hemoglobinuria, pallor, jaundice, anemia, elevated LDH, and flow cytometry showing deficiency of certain proteins on the surface of red blood cells would be suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is due to the deficiency of CD59. PNH is a rare acquired hematologic disorder characterized by a mutation of the PIG-A gene . This mutation results in a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)- anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells. This deficiency leads to the absence of important complement regulatory proteins, such as CD55 aka DAF (decay accelerating factor) and CD59 aka RIML (reactive inhibitor of membrane lysis) , which normally protect red blood cells from complement-mediated destruction. Consequently, red blood cells become sensitive to lysis by the complement system , particularly during periods of physical stress or following sleep. PNH is characterized by a triad of hemolysis + pancytopenia + venous thrombosis. Other symptoms include hemoglobinuria, fatigue, pallor, jaundice, abdominal pain, and recurrent infections. Flow cytometry (the gold standard for diagnosis): Shows the absence of CD55 and CD59. Factor H (Option D): Complement Factor H is a circulating glycoprotein that inhibits the alternative pathway by promoting the cleavage and destruction of C3b and the turnover of the C3 convertases. Factor H deficiency is associated with an atypical form of hemolytic uremic syndrome and age-related macular degeneration. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 788,789 Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 92

questions.question: Pain during inflammation is mediated by?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D) Bradykinin EXPLANATION: Bradykinin mediates pain during an inflammatory response Bradykinin is produced from the cleavage of high-molecular-weight kininogen by the action of kallikrein. It is a potent mediator of inflammation and pain , released in response to tissue injury and trauma . It acts on its receptors to induce vasodilation , increase vascular permeability , and stimulate the release of other inflammatory mediators. These actions contribute to the characteristic signs of inflammation, including redness, swelling, heat, and pain. Additionally, bradykinin can directly activate nociceptors (pain-sensing neurons), leading to the sensation of pain. The action of bradykinin is short-lived because it is quickly inactivated by an enzyme called kininase. Bradykinin has been implicated as a mediator in some forms of allergic reactions, such as anaphylaxis. (Serotonin) (Option A) Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) , is a neurotransmitter and vasoactive substance produced primarily by enterochromaffin cells in the gastrointestinal tract. It regulates mood, appetite , and sleep , as well as gastrointestinal motility and platelet aggregation . In the context of inflammation, serotonin released from platelets and mast cells can contribute to vasodilation , increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction . Its role in inflammation is less prominent compared to other mediators like histamine and bradykinin. (Leukotrienes) (Option B) Leukotrienes are lipid mediators synthesized from arachidonic acid metabolism, primarily by the 5-lipoxygenase pathway. They play a significant role in the pathogenesis of asthma and allergic reactions by inducing bronchoconstriction, increasing vascular permeability , and promoting the recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of inflammation. (Interleukin-1) (Option C) Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a proinflammatory cytokine produced by various cells, including macrophages, monocytes , and dendritic cells , in response to infection, injury, or inflammation. It plays a central role in the inflammatory response by inducing fever, activating immune cells , and promoting the production of other cytokines and inflammatory mediators. However, IL-1 is not a primary mediator responsible for the localized symptoms described in the clinical scenario, including pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth following a traumatic injury. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no. 86,88,89,92
